item.title: FOREIGN TERMS IN THE NEW TESTAMENT
item.description:
FOREIGN TERMS IN THE NEW TESTAMENT

Abaddon (Ἀβαδδών): “Destroyer” (Revelation 9:11**)

Abba (Αββα): “father” (Mark 14:36; Romans 8:15; Galatians 4:6**)

Akeldama (Ἀκελδαμάχ): “Field of Blood” (Acts 1:19**)

anathema (ἀνάθεμα): Galatians 1:9; 1 Corinthians 16:2

Armageddon (Ἁρμαγεδών): “The Hill of Megiddo” (Revelation 16:16**)

Bar-Jesus (Βαριησούς): Acts 13:6

(Simon) Bar-Jonah/Bar-Jonah (Βαιωνά/Βαριωνᾶς): “(Simon), son-of John” (Matthew

16:17)

Barnabas (Βαρναβᾶς):“Son of Consolation” (Acts 4:36 “which is interpreted [ὅ

ἐστιν μεθερμηνευόμενον]”)

Barsabbas (Βαρσαββᾶς): Joseph Barsabbas (Acts 1:23); Judas Barsabbas (Acts 15:22)

item.title: INTERJECTIONS
item.description:
INTERJECTIONS

ἄγε, James 4:13

ἴδε, John 1:29

δεῦρο, Mark 10:21

ἰδού, Matthew 11:10 absolutely; Revelation 4:1 (with article)

ἔα, Luke 4:34

οὐά, Mark 15:29 (with vocative)

οὐαί, Luke 6:25 (with vocative);

used absolutely οὐαί οὐαί (Ρεωελατιον 18:10, 16, 19

used with the dative as in Matthew 11:21; Luke 6:24-25

ὦ, with the vocative in Matthew 15:28

ὡς exclamatory particle in Romans 10:15

τί exclamatory particle in Lk. 12:49

Α. Τ. Robertson, A Grammar of the Greek New Testament in the Light of Historical Research, Broadman Press, 1934. 4th ed.

item.title: IRREGULAR LINGUISTIC FEATURES IN REVELATION:
item.description:
IRREGULAR LINGUISTIC FEATURES IN REVELATION:

INTERACTING WITH R. H. CHARLES

Three possibilities are always present when an irregularity occurs: it was intentional, it was due to ignorance, or it was an unintentional mistake. R. H. Charles wrote the two-volume commentary on Revelation in the International Critical Commentary. It presented an extended investigation of linguistic peculiarities in the Book of Revelation. He concluded that the writer was a Jew thinking in Hebrew and writing in Greek, which he did not know very well. Other writers, particularly Henry Cadbury, have challenged this conclusion, saying that the linguistic irregularities are deliberate. The issue is of some importance because it relates to the authorship issue for the Apocalypse. If the anomalies were deliberate, it is not as necessary to posit a different author for Revelation vs. the Gospel of John and the three Epistles of John, which do not have such grammatical features.

item.title: IV. Verbs
item.description:
IV. Verbs

A. Tenses

  1. present

a. simple/unidentified

b. progressive

c. iterative

d. gnomic/characteristic

e. conative

f. historic

g. futuristic present

h. past action continuing into the present

  1. future

a. simple/unidentified

b. progressive

c. declarative/imperatival

d. μέλλω + infinitive

  1. imperfect

a. progressive

b. iterative

c. ingressive (action)

d. conative/attempted

e. customary (“would” = good translation): Mark 3:11

f. unusual - for third-person plural: John 15:22, 24

  1. aorist

a. simple

b. ingressive (state)

item.title: PARTICLES
item.description:
PARTICLES

(“Particles” is a loose category that is not uniformly defined among Greek scholars. Some include in particles everything but nouns, pronouns, and verbs (A. T. Robertson); other include only the intensifying short words; many include prepositions, conjunctions, negatives, and modal adverbs.)

Enclitics [gev, a[n, mevn, pevr, rJav]

Postpositive [dhv, gev, mevn, pevr, toiv]

Non-enclitic particles [[a[ra, toigavr (toiv + ge + a[ra) toinu’n, nhv, naiv, ei| mhvn, ouj, mhv, mh; ouj]

item.title: QUESTIONED TEXTS IN THE NEW TESTAMENT
item.description:
QUESTIONED TEXTS IN THE NEW TESTAMENT

Below is a list of forty-one more noticeable places in the New Testament where the text is uncertain. About 80% of the variants occur in historical segments, which is a little less than 60% of the New Testament. Brackets mark the questioned portions. Double parentheses mark the more important and more doubtful of these readings. Quotations are from The Conversational Version.

Matthew 6:13b [because the kingdom, power, and glory

item.title: TIME AND DISTANCE TERMS
item.description:
TIME AND DISTANCE TERMS

The terms in this list are capable of functioning in terms of genitive of time within which, dative of time when, and/or accusative of extent of time.

ἀιών eternity

ἀλεκτροφωνία cockcrowing time, before dawn

ἅλφα first, beginning

ἀνατολή day, dawn

ἀρχή beginning, first

αὐγή daybreak, dawn

αὔριον tomorrow

γενεά generation

δευτερπαῖος on the second day, in two days

δευύτερος a second (time)

διετία two-year period

ejnautivo" five year

item.title: Try this: https://www.billmounce.com/freegreekfont/unicode-windows
item.description:
Try this: https://www.billmounce.com/freegreekfont/unicode-windows

I didn’t find the files I had before, but this is pretty good.

Once you get it installed, you should be able to find and print a keyboard map.

Otherwise you can make your own, for the accent marks, etc. Some are combinations using ctrl or alt.

I have used aftermarket keyboard programs before, some I thought were more intuitive than windows, but when a new version of windows comes out, they become obsolete.
